biblScope.title: A Guide to the Bible in Syriac

editorialDecl.p: This record created following the Syriaca.org guidelines. Documentation available at: http://syriaca.org/documentation.

interpretation.p: Approximate dates described in terms of centuries or partial centuries have been interpreted as documented in Syriaca.org Dates.

category.catDesc: The name used by Syriaca.org for document titles, citation, and disambiguation. These names have been created according to the Syriac.org guidelines for headwords: http://syriaca.org/documentation/headwords.html.
An anglicized version of a name, included to facilitate searching.
Indicates the content is canonical, i.e., widely agreed upon. Abbreviations of work titles are primarily in view.

langUsage.language: Unvocalized Syriac of any variety or period
Names or terms Romanized into English according to the standards adopted by the Gorgias Encyclopedic Dictionary of the Syriac Heritage

bibl.title: John (Peshitta version)
ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܟܪܘܙܘܬܐ ܕܝܘܚܢܢ
ܣܦܪܐ ܕܝܘܚܢܢ
John
John
ܐܶܘܰܓܶܠܺܝܳܘܢ ܩܰܕܺܝܫܳܐ ܟܳܪܘܽܙܘܽܬܳܐ ܕܝܘܽܚܰܢܳܢ ܟܳܪܘܽܙܳܐ
S. John
The Gospel of S. John, according to the Peshitta version
The Gospel of John, according to the Peshitta version
ܫܠܡ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܟܪܘܙܘܬܐ ܕܝܘܚܢܢ ܫܠܝܚܐ ܕܡܠܠ ܝܘܢܐܝܬ ܒܐܦܣܣ.
ܫܠܡ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܕܝܘܚܢܢ ܫܠܝܚܐ ܒܪ ܙܒܕܝ. ܕܐܬܦܫܩ ܡܢ ܝܘܚܢܢ ܐܦܝܣܩܘܦܐ ܕܩܘܣܛܝܛܝܢܦܘܠܝܣ. ܕܐܬܩܪܝ ܡܢ ܐܢܫܐ ܐܝܟ ܕܒܢܡܘܣܐ ܟܪܘܣܐܣܛܡܘܣ܀
ܫܠ̣ܡ ܠܡܟ̣ܬܒ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܟܪܘܙܘܬܐ ܕܝܘܚܢܢ ܫܠܝܚܐ: ܕܡܠܠ ܝܘܢܐܝܬ ܒܐܦܣܘܣ
The Gospel of John
The Gospel S. John, according to the Peshitta version
ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ
John, according to the Peshitta version
ܫܠܸܡ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܕܝܘܚܢܢ ܐܘܢܓܠܣܛܐ ܗ̇ܘ ܕܪܚ̇ܡ ܗܘ̣ܐ ܡܪܢ ܕܡܠܸܠ ܝܘܢܐܝܬ ܒܐܦܣܘܣ ܡܕܝܢܬܐ.
The Gospel of John according to the Peshitta version
ܫܠܡ ܠܡܟܬܒ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܘܢ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܟܪܘܙܘܬܐ ܕܝܘܚܢܢ ܫܠܝܚܐ ܚܕ ܡܢ ܬܪ̈ܥܣܪ ܕܡܠܠ ܝܘܢܐܝܬ ܒܐܦܣܣ. ܫܠܡ ܠܡܟܬܒ ܒܟܬܒܐ ܗܢܐ ܐܘ̈ܢܓܠܣܛܐ ܬܠܬܐ ܡܬܝ ܠܘܩܐ ܝܘܚܢܢ. .
bibl.note: The Gospel of John (Peshitta version) is a designation for a group of texts translating the Greek Gospel of John, beginning in the early 5th century and appearing in manuscripts as early as the 5th or 6th century. It bears similarities to previous Syriac translations, the Diatessaron and John (Old Syriac), but its exact relationship to these versions is still a matter of debate, as is the uniformity of the text itself. It generally reflects the Greek more closely than John (Old Syriac) does.
ܒܿܪܫܝܬܼ ܐܝܬܼܘܗ̱ܝ ܗ̱ܘܐ ܡܠܬܼܐ܂ ܘܗܘܼ ܡܠܬܼܐ܂ ܐܝܬܼܘܗ̱ܝ ܗ̱ܘܐ ܠܘܬܼ ܐܠܗܐ܂ ܘܐܠܗܐ ܐܝܬܼܘܗ̱ܝ ܗ̱ܘܐ ܗܘܼ ܡܠܬܼܐ܂
ܐܶܘܰܓܶܠܺܝܳܘܢ ܩܰܕܺܝܫܳܐ ܟܳܪܘܽܙܘܽܬܳܐ ܕܝܘܽܚܰܢܳܢ ܟܳܪܘܽܙܳܐ ܕܡܰܠܶܠ ܘܰܐܟܪܶܙ ܝܰܘܢܳܐܺܝܬ ܒܶܐܦܶܣܳܘܣ܀
